awd_abstract_narration:
Genome sequencing has provided a "parts list" for all life. The next great challenge is understanding what all those parts do. Toward this end, Dr. Featherstone is leading biology students to systematically search the genome for previously overlooked 'parts', with a specific focus on discovering uncharacterized genes required for brain development. Using this approach, Featherstone?s group discovered a fundamentally new type of protein that they named 'Optimus prime' (OPr). This project will focus on characterizing the function of OPr in order to expand our understanding of normal brain development.  Since human OPr has been linked to autism, bipolar disorder, and migraine, the work also has potential to inform our understanding of certain neurological diseases The project will provide training for a diverse group of students, including students from populations underrepresented in scientific disciplines and scientists who would otherwise not have access to leading research facilities. 

	OPr was discovered using genetic and biochemical screens in Drosophila melanogaster, which for over a century has proven an ideal tool for basic biological discovery. Preliminary studies suggest that OPr associates with specific glutamate receptor subunit mRNAs to control glutamate receptor subunit protein production and synaptic receptor subtype composition ? processes which are universally recognized as important for brain development and plasticity, but which are still very poorly understood. To test this idea, Dr. Featherstone and his team of students will engineer Drosophila completely lacking the OPr gene and then assay glutamate receptor production and function using a variety of powerful techniques. This will determine the functional role of OPr in the developing brain. In a separate line of experiments, Dr. Featherstone and his team will examine the biochemical and spatial relationship between OPr and mRNA, to better understand, at a molecular level, exactly how OPr works.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to develop a functional understanding of the novel protein 'Optimus prime' (OPr) in the fruit fly, Drosophila named by the Featherstone lab. Although Opr is a highly conserved gene, the role of Opr remains uncharacterized in any animal including humans. Over the course of this project we were successful in generating tools to study Opr in both Drosophila and mouse model organisms. In the fly, we generated a mutant lacking Opr using CRISPR technology, as well as flies overexpressing Opr. We also generated Opr antibodies to look at the protein expression pattern in the fly. Using these reagents, we were able to complete the first functional characterization of fly Opr, the results of which are published in the PhD thesis of Dr. Dina Beeler, who was assigned to this project. A manuscript summarizing this work entitled “Characterization of Optimus Prime, a novel regulator of synaptic transmission and growth at the Drosophila NMJ” has also been written and is ready for submission. Importantly, two undergraduates who worked on this project are included as co-authors on the journal article.

A second PhD student, Brian Grewe undertook a detailed expression profiling of mouse Opr (named Vwa8), throughout development. This study was published in Dr. Grewe’s PhD thesis as well as a manuscript entitled “The spatial and developmental expression of mouse Vwa8 (von Willebrand domain-containing protein 8)”. In addition, Dr. Grewe generated several reagents including a conditional (tm1c) mouse line for Vwa8 to produce a gene knockout. Multiple attempts to generate the null mutant failed to produce viable offspring, suggesting that in mice Vwa8 deletion may be lethal. However, this does not preclude other labs using tm1c to make conditional knockouts. To ensure that future studies can utilize this valuable mouse line, our mouse colonies have been established in the lab of our collaborator, Dr. Lawrence Mandarino at the University of Arizona, who intends to follow a promising line of enquiry into the role of Vwa8 in energy metabolism. These lines will also be made available to the scientific community at large upon request.

In all this award supported the training of two graduate students: Dina Beeler-Muscat and Brian Grewe, both of whom have successfully defended their PhDs and are now working in private industry. In addition, three undergraduate students have been intimately involved in the research supported by this grant.
